sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_07
sentences.sentence: Welcome to Euronews tonight. I'm Erin Zaydi. Here are the headlines.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_07
sentences.sentence: World Health Organization says Omicron variant is very transmissible but urges people not to panic, with cases continuing to rise, more countries impose restrictions.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_07
sentences.sentence: Trying to contain the spread of Omicron, countries introduce further curbs on school children as vaccinations for under-12s gains momentum.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_04
sentences.sentence: Russia increases its state control over the popular social network VK.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_04
sentences.sentence: We'll be speaking to our Russia analyst here in the queue.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_07
sentences.sentence: Will Omicron take a bite out of the hospitality and entertainment industries over the festive period?

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_07
sentences.sentence: We'll be discussing that and more in Talking Culture.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_07
sentences.sentence: The World Health Organization's chief scientist is warning that while the new Covid Omicron variant is very transmissible, people shouldn't be panicking.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_07
sentences.sentence: The WHO says that so far it has not seen any reports of Omicron related deaths.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_07
sentences.sentence: It is urging people to be prepared, but emphasised that it's important not to rush to any conclusions.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_07
sentences.sentence: The Global Health Body says the world is much better prepared now than a year ago, given the development of vaccines.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_07
sentences.sentence: More than 1% of the German population is currently infected with COVID. The leading institute in charge of monitoring the pandemic estimates that more than 925,000 people are actively infected with the virus. It's seeing a spike of almost 75,000 new cases every day. Health Minister Jens Spahn said the unvaccinated are becoming seriously ill at a much greater rate than those who've been jabbed.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_07
sentences.sentence: In Belgium, the Prime Minister announced a raft of new restrictions to try and stem the spread of Omicron as hospitals face intense pressure.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_07
sentences.sentence: All indoor events, with a few exceptions, will be banned.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_07
sentences.sentence: Primary schools and kindergartens face a range of measures and will close a week early for Christmas holidays. Face masks will now have to be worn by children as young as six. Alexander Ducroux says getting vaccinated is an act of solidarity.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_07
sentences.sentence: Let's head now to Brussels and to our correspondent Shona Murray who's there for us in the Belgian capital.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_07
sentences.sentence: So Shona, this is the third time in the past few weeks that Belgium has introduced new measures.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_07
sentences.sentence: How bad is the situation there in Belgium?

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_05
sentences.sentence: Well, Belgium is the third highest infection rate in Europe and obviously that has having implications for hospitalisations, in particular ICUs, where there's a disproportionate number of unvaccinated people there.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_05
sentences.sentence: And as you mentioned then, there's a few restrictions that have been imposed today, such as children leaving school early on the 18th of December.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_05
sentences.sentence: But that's actually in order for teachers to get their booster shots because you heard there from Alexander Ducroux, the Belgian Prime Minister.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_05
sentences.sentence: He said there are 8,000 fewer deaths and 30 000 fewer hospitalizations because of the vaccination process belgium has a relatively high vaccination process programs right over 70 but in brussels it's just under 60. so there is a push from the belgian government to get better vaccination particularly in preparation for the omicron variant even though we don't know exactly how infectious that's going to be. Now, Shona, all week we've been talking about mandatory vaccinations across the bloc. Now, you spoke to the Belgian virologist, Mark Van Rans. What did he have to say about that? Yeah, he said it's an extremely tough question and very tough call for countries.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_05
sentences.sentence: If you have a low vaccination rate over 60%, then it may get you over the hump, he says. But if you have a high vaccination rate, then it may just create that level of division that those in the far right that seek to sow disinformation around vaccines and how they impact people, that that could be really something that they really want to hear. They have these conspiracy theories that vaccinations are part of a global conspiracy.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_05
sentences.sentence: And he said that this may feed right into them.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_07
sentences.sentence: Shona, thanks.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_05
sentences.sentence: It's from Belgium. Thank you so much.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_07
sentences.sentence: More countries across Europe are now looking at rolling out vaccines for children.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_07
sentences.sentence: Austria started jabbing at 5 to 11-year-olds last month.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_07
sentences.sentence: for children. Austria started jabbing at 5 to 11 year olds last month. Let's now go to Kike Bassett, a paediatrician and research professor at the Barcelona Institute for Global Health.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_00
sentences.sentence: Thanks so much for joining us on Euronews tonight. Now, countries around the world, they're of course expanding their COVID-19 vaccination programmes now to include young children. The EU has backed this move for its member states and a handful of members of the bloc are now offering jabs for under 12. So what role could this really play when it comes to this fifth wave? Well it could play a very important role, particularly in those countries which already have a relatively high vaccination coverage. We are seeing that the new

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_07
sentences.sentence: infections and the new wave are led by infections in children particularly in children under the age of 12 which are the ones which have not started to be vaccinated. So vaccinating in those specific age group could have an important toll and contribute to the contention of the transmission globally not only at the individual level now we were just hearing from our reporter there about the new rules coming into place uh recovered in belgium now belgium has introduced masks for children above six years old um it's stream it seems very strong given what we've been told about COVID less likely to affect children.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_07
sentences.sentence: But might this possibly help with cluster transmission?

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_07
sentences.sentence: Sure, sure it will.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_00
sentences.sentence: We have the experience here in Spain that children are obliged to wear masks in schools since September 2020.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_00
sentences.sentence: And this led to a very low transmission rate within schools, even before vaccines were introduced in the country.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_00
sentences.sentence: Everything that can be done to limit transmission from and to children is going to help, obviously, in containing transmission at the more general population level.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_07
sentences.sentence: Sure. I mean, so just to pick up on what you said there about everything should be done to limit the transmission.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_00
sentences.sentence: So all of these new restrictions, will they also help ensure the rights of children to having a full and proper education? And perhaps could these new measures then stop countries sort of whole scale closing schools down like we're seeing in the run up to Christmas? Yes, and we have to reflect on the toll of closing down schools in the mental health and well-being of children. Face-to-face school is a fundamental right of children. They've been subject to many difficulties because not being able to go to face-to-face school during the entire pandemic. We should have learned a lot about this in the past 20 months.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_00
sentences.sentence: We need to provide the right for them to go back face-to-face to school. And there are measures, and the example of Spain is paradigmatic in terms of how well transmission was dealt with in schools while maintaining fully presential classes during the entire 2021 academic year.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_04
sentences.sentence: Okay, Kike Bas, we have to leave it there, but thank you so much for joining us on the programme tonight. Thank you. To Russia now us on the program tonight thank you to russia now where the state-owned energy company gasprom has gained control of the country's most popular social network vk critics say the move represents russia's increased effort to control online conversations matthew the cube has more on that story matthew well chances are if you live in russia belarus or another eastern european country you'll in Russia, Belarus, or another Eastern European country, you'll have heard of VKontakt or VK.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_04
sentences.sentence: The popular social network, which looks a lot like Facebook, claims to reach 90% of the Russian online speaking audience.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_04
sentences.sentence: It was launched back in 2007, and although it has been accused of being close to the Russian government, it was officially independent.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_04
sentences.sentence: Some of its shares are owned by a holding company of the Russian billionaire, it was officially independent. Some of its shares are owned by a holding company of the Russian billionaire, Alisher Usmanov. But on Thursday, those shares were sold to Gazprom, the Russian state energy giant, which of course also has ties to the President Vladimir Putin. Gazprom has recently been seen as instrumental in trying to bring the internet in Russia under the control of the authorities. Moscow says this is an attempt to combat online extremism but critics say their efforts are trying to limit political debate and inhibit free speech. Well for more analysis on exactly what this Gazprom move to VK means let's cross over to Paris where we can speak to Euronews Russia analyst Galina Polonskaya. Galina, Gazprom is saying that VK is going to remain an independent company, but how significant is this change of shares?

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_01
sentences.sentence: Well, Matthew, very significant and symbolic, I would say.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_04
sentences.sentence: You see, VK is Russia's biggest social media platform with more than 100 million users, and most live in Russia. It's more than half of the population. And now it's under control of Gazprom and SoG that it will be Vladimir Kiriyenko, who is the son of the deputy head of the presidential administration, Sergey Kiriyenko. used to be in 2014 its creator Pavel Durov had to sell its share and he explained in interviews that he had a conflict with the Russian Federal Security Bureau over the privacy and protection of data of the users. He had to leave the country. So now what does this deal mean right now? Well, some critics say that it is very, very symbolic and means that the Russian state is finally taking a total control over a key part of Russia's social media online space Galina we've previously seen content related to Russian opponents on social media networks being limited by the Russian authorities how significant is this latest move when it comes to free speech in the country?

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_01
sentences.sentence: Well, you see, Matthew, critics now say that very soon we will see real censorship in the Internet in Russia, which is still quite a free space, so we can read independent media, we can watch independent channels, many of which have been recently labeled foreign agents in Russia.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_01
sentences.sentence: But we have also seen very alarming signs.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_01
sentences.sentence: We have seen huge fines against Twitter, against Google or Apple.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_01
sentences.sentence: And during the parliamentary elections, indeed, Apple and Google agreed to remove the application, the smart voting application of the jailed critic Alexei Navalny from the Russia's web space.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_01
sentences.sentence: And recently, Russian communications watchdog Rosspotrebnadzor have published a list of 13 big companies, such as Twitter, Google, Facebook, and Zoom, and others.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_01
sentences.sentence: And they are obliged to open their representative offices in Russia as early as the beginning of the next year and they will also have to remove all of the contact which is the context which is which is against the Russian law from the web space and if they do not comply they risk to be actually closed and shut down in the Russian web. So many in Russia, many critics are saying that the iron curtain in the Internet in Russia is ready to drop down any minute and that Russians will have only the domestic content. And by the way, Gazprom media has just launched a Russian version of the Chinese TikTok.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_04
sentences.sentence: Euronews Russia analyst Galina Polanskaya there. So Mariam you can certainly hear it's significant that Gazprom is now gaining more control over Russian social media and also that VK CEO stepping down as a result of this stakeholder shake-up. Welcome back to the program.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_07
sentences.sentence: The men's tennis governing body, the ATP, has been criticised for not joining the Women's Tennis Association in suspending all tournaments in China over concerns about player Peng Shuai.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_07
sentences.sentence: The Association of Tennis Professionals said Peng's situation raises serious concerns but fell short of counselling any events in China.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_07
sentences.sentence: The International Olympic Committee said they are also sharing the concern about her well-being and says it will not be allowed to meet Peng, it will be allowed to meet Peng in person next month. Peng disappeared following sexual assault allegations she made against one of the country's most powerful politicians.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_07
sentences.sentence: Yaqiu Wang, senior China researcher at the Human Rights Watch, joins me now from New York.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_07
sentences.sentence: Thanks so much for being on the program.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_07
sentences.sentence: So the IOC has been criticized this week for its stand on Peng Shuai.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_07
sentences.sentence: It says it's using quiet diplomacy to resolve this case.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_07
sentences.sentence: Do you think that's the way to really tackle this?

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_08
sentences.sentence: I don't think that's the right way to tackle this, especially not the way that the IOC tried to tackle this? I don't think that's the right way to tackle this, especially not the the way that IOC tried to tackle this, which is to participate in the Chinese government's propaganda to construct a narrative that Peng Shuai is free. The Chinese government in the past have disappeared many people and then make them reappear to say you know I'm doing well don't worry about me this fits into the you into the government's past of doing that.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_08
sentences.sentence: And the IOC to participate in that is shameful.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_07
sentences.sentence: Now the WTA, they've suspended all competitions in China, but the men's side, their tennis association, they haven't done that.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_07
sentences.sentence: So what impact will the WTA's decision really have then?

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_08
sentences.sentence: impact will the WTA's decision really have then? Well, I think the WTA, what has the WTA done is inspiring. It says, you know, human rights is bigger than business. We are going to prioritize the asset safety over our profits. It's inspiring. It's disappointing to see ATP not falling suit.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_07
sentences.sentence: But I think that in the long run, WTA stands well, you know, galvanize other organizations to do the same. Now, we've seen appearances, of course, by Peng Chui over the past few weeks. She's just made another one saying she's safe and well.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_08
sentences.sentence: How much credibility can these appearances or do they have really I don't think they have any credibility I mean as I said this happened to many people in China before whether you had a human rights lawyer who criticized the government or it is you're a celebrity a business person who somehow did something the government doesn't like they got disappeared and they say on TV, well, I'm doing well.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_08
sentences.sentence: But some of them later left China, they recanted their story and they said, you know, I was forced to say that I was doing well.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_08
sentences.sentence: So, you know, this could have happened to Peng Shuai.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_07
sentences.sentence: And so how, you know, just lastly then, how important is it that the international focus keeps on the plight of Peng? i think it's very important of you know doing this job for this years i realized that the attention the pressure keeps people in china safer than they would have been had there not been international attention the government understand that if the world is watching they needed to be more cautious in what they do. Yaqiu Wang, Senior Researcher at the Human Rights Watch, thank you so much for joining us tonight on the program. Thank you so much.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_07
sentences.sentence: Just as we were all starting to go back to live concerts and events and really feel normal again, along comes the Omicron variant to well put a stop to all of it the pandemic has of course already severely impacted the culture sector so could new restrictions impact it all again especially as we head into the festive season well let's now talk to our culture correspondent andrea belitho joins me right here right now um so sadly um you know we're heading into christmas this is as i say the most wonderful time of the year and but thanks this new variant possibly not exactly um we've had a few months off talking about covert and culture but here we are once again um in england some of the biggest theaters are now saying mask wearing is mandatory for all performances. The Royal Opera House, the venues in the West End where Andrew Lloyd Webber's musicals are playing, for example.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_06
sentences.sentence: Here in Lyon, there's a massive festival next week, the Fête de Lumière.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_06
sentences.sentence: This is still going to go ahead, organisers have said, but now you have to wear a mask, even though it's outdoors.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_06
sentences.sentence: But given that it attracts around two million visitors, I guess that's not perhaps that surprising.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_06
sentences.sentence: Further south in Montpellier, a music festival, Isle of Techno, has been postponed until April.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_06
sentences.sentence: And even in Germany, the Berlinale, the big Berlin international film festival, is exploring contingency plans, possibly including a delay.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_06
sentences.sentence: Right, well, I guess we'll have to start looking at those refund policies policies the small print in all these events that we go to. Okay so you mentioned Berlin there and well let's go to the Angela Merkel obviously and her choice of farewell song has raised a few eyebrows hasn't it? Yes yes it has indeed at her kind of a farewell official public goodbye, she had three songs played by a military band, and one of them was You Forgot the Colour Film

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_06
sentences.sentence: by the German punk singer Nina Hagen.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_06
sentences.sentence: Should we take a quick listen to it then?

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_06
sentences.sentence: Let's.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_06
sentences.sentence: Let's do that. Yeah, it's about, I mean, you couldn't hear it from there, but it's about a boyfriend who only packs a black and white film when he goes on holiday to take pictures of the old communist Germany.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_06
sentences.sentence: And it's a tribute, of course, to Angela Merkel's East German upbringing.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_06
sentences.sentence: She says, this song was a highlight of my youth.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_06
sentences.sentence: Well, who'd have thought she was a bit of a punk rocker?

sentences.sentence: Let's now turn to the Turner Prize honours visual art, of course.

sentences.sentence: This year, all the nominees were collectives, were they?

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_06
sentences.sentence: Yes, that's right.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_06
sentences.sentence: The Turner Prize said all nominees would be collectives who'd helped inspire social change through art.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_06
sentences.sentence: And as, of course, galleries have had such a turbulent time over the last year, the Turner Prize said that, for once, nominees didn't have to have had a major show in the run-up.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_06
sentences.sentence: So it was the Array Coll the array collective there a Belfast activist group who recreated an Irish pub and won the prize now this pub was decorated with with banners about reproductive rights and LGBTQ issues and a list of pub rules including you must have a laugh right and so from the amazing Turner Prize to something little bit less known perhaps the Turnip Prize what's that about? Yeah this is an annual competition run by a pub in Somerset and it's basically it's a bit of a parody of the Turner Prize itself. It goes to the person who creates a very bad artwork with the least amount of effort and this year it was won by a soft toy, a soft black and white panda with a little label around its neck saying Mick. So panda, Mick, pandemic. It was a play on the word. That is actually awful.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_07
sentences.sentence: Wonderful or awful. Yeah. Thank you so much for all of that, Andrea. Thank you so much. Okay.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_07
sentences.sentence: This week, commuters in Milan were in for a rare treat by murals by the street artist Banksy, where we created in the Italian city's main train station.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_07
sentences.sentence: Clemence Waller reports.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_03
sentences.sentence: The exhibition, The World of Banksy, The Immersive Experience, will feature some of the elusive artists' best-known pieces.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_00
sentences.sentence: We are not only talking about recreating the stencils in their original size, but also recreating the walls on which Banksy actually painted.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_03
sentences.sentence: When it was a brick wall, we made a brick wall.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_00
sentences.sentence: When it is a cement wall, we made a brick wall. When it is a cement wall, we made a cement wall.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_00
sentences.sentence: When they are dirty from time and pollution, we made them dirty with special effects.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_03
sentences.sentence: The pieces on display include a businessman with a three-legged dog, a little schoolgirl with a tire on fire, the mild-mild West, a girl painting over a swastika, and many more pieces tied to his activism.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_03
sentences.sentence: Banksy is known for his sharp criticism of social inequalities and political hypocrisy. over a swastika and many more pieces tied to his activism.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_03
sentences.sentence: Banksy is known for his sharp criticism of social inequalities and political hypocrisy.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_03
sentences.sentence: This location is very much adapted to this exhibit because it unites the history of the train station, a very beautiful construction from another era, but it's also a street, it's a fleeting place, some place you go through and leave, and that is what Banksy is all about, a tradition that unites with modern times." Over 130 frescoes are being showcased until February 27th, inviting thousands of travelers to take a moment and reflect on the messages behind the works.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_07
sentences.sentence: The show is a follow-up to an earlier Milan exhibition that later traveled around the world. From one visual treat to another, we will leave you with a no comment from France, where the Lantern Festival is illuminating cities and fascinating visitors.
